thread.title: 'Bloody hot': shearers and graziers battle extreme temperatures as state roasts
thread.title_full: 'Bloody hot': shearers and graziers battle extreme temperatures as state roasts

author: Peter Hannam
title: 'Bloody hot': shearers and graziers battle extreme temperatures as state roasts
text:
Egg the pug stolen in Olympic Park mugging Egg the pug stolen in Olympic Park mugging 
Police say three thieves allegedly held a man at knife-point and stole his wallet, backpack and his pet dog at Sydney Olympic Park on Thursday night. Courtesy Seven News . More videos NSW heatwave: hottest February day on record predicted 
An extraordinary heatwave scorching much of NSW is set to bring yet more grief, with health authorities issuing an air pollution alert for increased levels of ozone in the atmosphere in Sydney. Vision courtesy ABC News 24. 
On Friday, his team of 11 - eight men and three women - were toiling in extreme conditions near Carinda, relieving 451 sheep of their fleece in temperatures that nudged towards 50 degrees. 
"We ran out of sheep otherwise we'd have kept going," Mr Lunn, 64, said during a visit to Dubbo which was expecting a relatively cool maximum of 45 degrees on Saturday. "Everyone's got to make a dollar, you know." Related Content Threat of blackouts looms as NSW bakes in heatwave 
Shearing sheds typically have a few fans to give shearers and their teams picking up and sorting the wool a breather. Smaller sheds heat up more, though, because the animals have to remain outside before they can shorn. 
To beat the heat, teams start at 6am and take breaks every two hours or pack it in if conditions become unbearable. Lately, though, that pattern has been disrupted by the incessant heat. Advertisement 
"It's just won't cool down," said Mr Lunn, who lives "about 40 miles" from Walgett. 
In fact, White Cliffs to the south set a new record minimum for any month in NSW on Saturday morning, with the mercury dipping only to 34.2 degrees, beating the previous mark of 34 degrees set in Ivanhoe in December 1994, according to Bureau of Meteorology data. SHARE
